results.title: A Land lived in
results.creator_credit: Alan Harper, Campbell Harper Films and National Trust for Scotland
results.brief_description: The work of the National Trust for Scotland. By restoring and protecting the properties and estates which have been placed under its care, the Trust helps to preserve the great historical and artistic landmarks of Scotland. The film brings out the historical associations of famous places, with a background of Scottish folk song.

results.title: A Jig: The River Cree
results.creator_credit: Stanley Russell and Thames and Clyde Film Company
results.brief_description: Introduction to a traditional Scottish dance the jig, set to the music of “The River Cree. Demonstrates the steps and movements of the four couples in a complete jig.

results.title: A is for atom
results.creator_credit: General Electric and John Sutherland Productions
results.brief_description: Explains by animation the nature of a single atom and its nucleus, the way in which atoms differ from one another, and the significance of the terms radioactive and stable. Describes the experiments which led to nuclear fission, the separation of mass uranium for the first atomic bomb, and the mass production of the artificial element plutonium. Explains the functioning of an atomic pile and the peace-time uses of atomic energy in agriculture, industry, transportation and medicine.

results.title: A Hole in one
results.brief_description: An early animated film about a farmer and his attempts to ride his pet goat. Efforts by the local policeman to ride the goat also fail. The goat finally charges at the farmer and butts him head first into the 18th hole, hence the title of the film

results.title: A Gift to grow on
results.creator_credit: George Zabriskie and U.S. Committee for UNICEF
results.brief_description: The United Nations Children’s Fund. US committee for UNICEF gets ready for its biggest workload. This documentary explains to young children exactly where this money goes. Its example: a poor town in Mexico where UNICEF provides medical help, education and entertainment.

results.title: Birth reborn
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
Looks at the work in France of Dr Michael Odent who firmly opposes standard medical thinking on childbirth practices. He advocates that women should be able to give birth in the position in which they feel most comfortable rather than being forced into the “stranded beetle” (legs in stirrups) position commonly used in hospitals. Shows a series of births in which Dr Odent helps women to give birth naturally and with a minimum amount of pain. Also depicts the work of Dr Odent in his pre-birth classes where he encourages women to give birth in different positions: standing or squatting. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: Lost in a crowd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
In this essay on loneliness, five characters in search of someone are sitting on a train. The film shows how each has unsuccessfully tried to remedy their situation. All five share a common problem yet as the train goes down the line not a word is spoken.

results.title: The Shape of ships to come
results.creator_credit: Don Scheldrup, Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
A look at the guided missile frigate HMAS Adelaide, a new breed of ship in the destroyer class. It is the first Australian warship to be fitted with gas turbine engines, to have helicopter carrying capabilities and to be equipped with the over horizon missile ‘Harpoon’.
